column1: 7953`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2012cnstRpts/oct/20121029_Dickens_26w.pdf`Success`Success`6`6`Not a fillable PDF.`"       DEPA RTM EN T OF WATER MANAGEM EN T   C ITY  OF CHICAGO    CUSTOMER NOTICE INFRASTRUCTURE RENEWAL PROGRAM               October 29
column3: At Alderman Roberto Maldonado’s (26th Ward) request
column4: I am providing you with information  regarding a water construction project in your neighborhood. This is part of our approach to  renewing our city’s aging infrastructure. I see this as an opportunity to partner with you our  customers. As part of this partnership
column5: I want to be certain you are well informed about the  project. You should know where to call if you have any questions or concerns.     Our crews will soon be installing 3
column6: 109 feet of 8-inch water main in W. Dickens Avenue
column7: from  N. Hamlin Avenue to N. Spaulding Avenue. The old pipe dates back to 1893 and needs to be  replaced.    We are coordinating with Alderman Maldonado’s office
column8: and he has made clear we are to put  great importance on your convenience and the quality of life in this neighborhood through the  whole term of this project. Good communication is the key.     I have asked my staff to assemble the attached information for you and to monitor the project  closely. We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do  everything possible to minimize inconvenience and noise and to conduct ourselves as good and  thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.     If you have questions or comments about the project
column9: please feel free to contact Assistant  Commissioner Tom LaPorte at 312-742-1021 at any time
column10: you may leave a message.     I am also asking you to consider the enclosed information about our MeterSave Program and our  Basement Flooding Partnership (BFP).     Sincerely
column12: P.E.  Commissioner    cc:   Alderman Roberto Maldonado                   26th Ward    1 0 0 0   E A S T   O H I O   S T R E E T
column13: C H I C A G O
column14: I L L I N O I S     6 0 6 1 1          Do you wonder what was happening in 1893?  That’s the year the old water main was installed  beneath your street.  Among other things:       MAE WEST                          The World’s Columbian Exposition opened in Chicago.    Henry Perky and William Ford patented shredded wheat.    The first bowling magazine
column16: was published.    France issued the first driver’s licenses
column17: which included a required test.    Katharine Lee Bates wrote ""America the Beautiful
column18: in Colorado.    Lizzie Borden was acquitted in the murder of her parents in New Bedford
column19: Massachusetts.     New Zealand became the first country to grant all its women the right to vote.    Actress Mae West was born.             DICKENS AVE. WATER PROJECT   PROJECT DESCRIPTION     Project:  The Department of Water Management will soon be installing 3
column20: 109 feet of 8-inch  water main in W. Dickens Avenue
column21: from N. Hamlin Avenue to N. Spaulding Avenue.    Reason:  The old main consists of 6-inch pipe
column22: and we want to expand capacity. Further
column23: the old  pipe dates back to 1893 and needs to be replaced.      Timing:  We will begin installing the new water main shortly
column24: and expect the water main work  to be completed by late January 2013. Restoration will follow in mid April 2013. Dates may  change depending on weather and other factors. If there is any appreciable change
column25: we will notify  you.    Traffic: We will allow traffic to flow on W. Dickens Avenue outside of our working hours.   When we are working in the street
column26: we have to close it to traffic for reasons of safety. You will  always be able to reach your home or business
column27: even if it means putting a metal plate in place.   Outside of working hours
column28: a lane will be left open for local traffic only.     Parking: We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed
column29: during work hours. We are  agreeable to parking outside of those hours
column30: but will have to insist that cars be moved by the start  of the next workday. We will try to preserve as much parking as we can.     CONTACT NUMBERS   24-HOUR SERVICE AND INFORMATION LINE      ALDERMAN ROBERTO MALDONADO   ASSISTANT WATER MANAGEMENT COMMISSIONER TOM LAPORTE   3-1-1   773-395-0143   312-742-1021                                                    FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS               What if there is a problem?  There are always surprises in any construction project.  If you  have any concerns or questions
column31: you can ask our foreman in the street.  You can also call  Assistant Commissioner Tom LaPorte directly at 312-742-1021.  His cell is on the voicemail  message
column32: in case it’s off hours.    Can I park when you’re not working? We have no problem with you parking outside of our  working hours.  We have to insist that cars be out of our way at the start of the workday.     Will this ever end?  Yes.  As a matter of fact
column33: the water main job is slated to conclude in late  January 2013. Restoration will follow in mid April 2013. We always hesitate to promise specific  dates
column34: since we are at the mercy of other factors like weather and emergencies elsewhere in town.    Will you shut my water off? Yes
column35: maybe a couple of times. When we switch over the services  from the old main to the new main
column36: we interrupt service. We give you 24-hour notice when this  is to happen.  In any construction project
column37: there is also a risk that an old pipe will break.  They  can be fragile. This may necessitate an emergency shutdown.  If we do this
column38: we will let you know  what is happening
column39: even though we may be unable to give prior warning.    Why should I be nice about this?  The crew working in the street will work hard to be good  neighbors
column40: and to respect both your convenience and your quality-of-life.  By working together
column41: we can complete this important project as friends working for the improvement of our  community.               DOES YOUR BASEMENT FLOOD?     The Department of Water Management would like to work with you and your neighbors to  reduce the risk of basement flooding.  We are promoting a collective response as the only  strategy—homeowners joining together on a neighborhood basis to work with us on  practical steps (public and private) to protect your property and peace of mind.    Want to learn more?  http://www.cityofchicago.org/watermanagement/bfp             DEPA RTM EN T OF WATER MANAGEM EN T            C ITY  OF CHICAGO    What is MeterSave?    MeterSave is a program to encourage Chicago homeowners to voluntarily install meters to  monitor water usage. Meters allow single family and two-flat homeowners to pay for only the  water actually used
column42: encouraging efforts to save water and money while protecting one of our  most precious natural resources.    Water charges in non-metered homes are tied to factors such as building size
column43: lot-size and  number of plumbing fixtures. Metered homes are billed according to actual use. This means that  with minimal effort
column44: participating homeowners could save money on their water bills.      Homeowner Incentives   Non-metered homeowners participating in MeterSave are eligible for the following:    A 7-year guarantee that the home water bill will be no higher than it would have if the meter   had not been installed. Bill will not exceed the assessed rate for that year.     Choice of one of the following (while supplies last):   rain barrel
column45:     water meter monitor (a refrigerator magnet that shows water usage)    outdoor water conservation kit or      And
column46: two of the above incentives if a whole block volunteers!   indoor water conservation kit      Frequently Asked Questions:   How and when do I sign up?   Interested non-metered single family and two-flat homeowners may visit www.metersave.org
column48: or call 312-744-4H2O. Please have your 12-digit account number ready.  Space is  limited based on funding availability and the number of volunteers.     What will it cost to participate?  The City of Chicago Department of Water Management will install a water meter complete with  the automatic meter reading (AMR) technology in your home FREE of charge.    AMR technology allows readings to be transmitted via wireless radio technology to Water  Management vehicles as they drive by
column49: eliminating the need for readings to take place inside the  home.  Bills will be issued bi-monthly and reflect only the actual amount of water used.     Do I have to be current on my water bill?  Yes.  Homeowners must be current on payment plan and water bill to participate in this limited  time offer of a 7-year guarantee.    For payment plan information call 312-744-4H20 (4426).      1 0 0 0   E A S T   O H I O   S T R E E T
column50: C H I C A G O
column51: I L L I N O I S     6 0 6 1 1            When can I have a meter installed?  Online meter installation scheduling is available at www.metersave.org  Otherwise
column52: Water  Management will contact you to schedule a time for meter installation.      Small changes made by Chicagoans can have a tremendous impact on the sustainability of  our water supply
column53: such as:     Turn off the faucet while brushing your teeth or shaving.  This can save over 500 gallons  per month per person.    Install high-efficiency
column54: low-flow toilets.  Toilets alone consume 26% of household water  consumption.  A leaky toilet wastes 200 gallons of water per day.    Install high-efficiency washing machines. This can save energy and water consumption.    Fill the sink with dishwater instead of washing dishes with an open tap.  This saves 25  gallons per wash.    If you own a dishwasher
column55: wait until you have a full load to run it.  Dishwashers typically  use half the energy
column57: and less soap than washing dishes in the sink.    Garden with plants that are native to Chicago.  This can reduce outdoor water use by 20- 50%.    Use rain barrels to capture rainwater for watering lawns and gardens.    Use a timer or a rain sensor to monitor lawn irrigation: Sprinkler systems use thousands  of gallons of water per cycle.  Installing a timer or rain sensor will save money and water by  preventing needless watering.         WATER   Our Most Precious Resource   Lake Michigan has lost almost 32 trillion gallons of water--the equivalent of over 45 million  Olympic-sized swimming pools of water-- over the past decade. Our region could face severe  water shortages by 2050 if we fail to take decisive action.     More than half of water consumption in Chicago occurs within homes.   Over 5.4 million people-- 44% of the population of the State of Illinois
column58: depend on the Chicago  Department of Water Management to provide a reliable supply of drinking water from Lake  Michigan.     Volunteer for a meter today to save water and money!           Please go to www.metersave.org     By phone call 3-1-1

column2: Technical and Analytical Group Purchasing and Supply Series  CLASS TITLE:  Director of Purchase Contract Administration   CHARACTERISTICS OF THE CLASS:  Under direction
column3: the class manages and directs staff engaged in the negotiation
column4: preparation and administration of contracts for the procurement of commodities and services; and performs related duties as required.  ESSENTIAL DUTIES:  Supervises staff and coordinates contract administration work for a specific area of procurement such as construction and engineering
column6: automotive and heavy equipment or professional services; oversees and participates in the negotiation of prices
column7: terms and conditions of contracts with vendors and consultants; reviews contract documents prepared by staff to ensure conformance to specifications
column8: compliance with legal and contract requirements and disabled/minority/women (DBE/MBE/WBE) owned enterprise guidelines; acts as liaison
column9: interpreting and explaining purchasing and payment procedures and mediating contract disputes between vendors and user departments; develops and implements contract administration procedures to ensure efficient consistent processing of contracts; reviews contract packages submitted by staff for appropriateness of recommendations and to ensure procurement needs of user departments are being met; approves contract modifications submitted by staff; supervises the provision of technical assistance to contractors on resolving deficiencies affecting the administration and approval of procurement contracts; prepares the section’s work activity reports for management use.  RELATED DUTIES:  Attends conferences and community and business forums to provide information on the City’s procurement process and related programs.  MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS:  Training and Experience.  Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Bachelor’s degree supplemented by five years of progressively responsible experience in the procurement of a variety of materials
column12: including two years of supervisory experience
column13: or an equivalent combination of training and experience is required.  Code: 1525 Administrative Service Statistical
column14: Technical and Analytical Group Purchasing and Supply Series  CLASS TITLE:  Director of Purchase Contract Administration  (Cont’d)  Knowledge
column15: Abilities and Skill.  Comprehensive knowledge of the principles of contract administration.  Comprehensive knowledge of the City’s procurement policies and procedures.  Considerable knowledge of RFP preparation.  Considerable knowledge of the standard language
column16: terms and conditions used in procurement contracts.  Considerable knowledge of contract specification development.       Ability to manage a contract administration division.  Ability to develop and implement contract purchasing procedures and standards.  Ability to establish and implement policies and procedures relative to the purchasing process.  Ability and willingness to administer appropriate employee disciplinary action when necessary.  Considerable skill in the application of the principles of contract administration.  Considerable skill in processing contracts.  Considerable analytical skills.  Considerable skill in negotiating contracts.  Skill in designing and implementing contract monitoring and compliance systems.  Good supervisory and management skills.  Excellent oral and written communication skills.   Working Conditions.  General office environment.   Equipment.  Standard office equipment including personal computers.  NOTE:  While the list of essential duties is intended to be as inclusive as possible
column17: there may be other duties which are essential to particular positions within the class.  July

column3: and Analytical  Series: Real Estate and Legal            CLASS TITLE: SUPERVISING PARALEGAL  CHARACTERISTICS OF THE CLASS      Under general supervision
column4: coordinates and supervises the work of paralegals providing  paraprofessional legal
column7: and performs related duties  as required      ESSENTIAL DUTIES   •  Prioritizes and makes work assignments to staff to ensure that attorneys receive needed   support and assistance with caseloads    •  Monitors the preparation of legal documents (e.g.
column10: subpoenas) and  related summaries by staff and reviews completed work to ensure accuracy and consistency  with departmental policies    •  Trains and instructs subordinate staff on paralegal functions
column12: and   departmental operating procedures   •  Maintains staff time records  •  Reviews and examines legal digests to conduct in-depth legal research for attorneys' use in   court proceedings    •  Provides technical assistance to paralegals engaged in abstracting complex transcripts and   briefings    •  Consults with division attorneys and private counsel to facilitate the case discovery process  •  Oversees the maintenance of court documents  •  Supervises the indexing and filing of court documents and depositions and/or creates and trains   staff on customized computer applications for these purposes   •  Creates and supervises the production of visual exhibits (e.g.
column15: charts) used at   trial and hearings and develops methods and procedures to display the information as required    •  Oversees the filing of court documents for various litigation efforts   •  Serves as a liaison with other City departments to facilitate information exchange    NOTE:  The list of essential duties is not intended to be inclusive; there may be other duties that are   essential to particular positions within the class.        MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS   Education
column17: and Experience  •  Graduation from an accredited college or university with a Bachelor's degree in Political   Science

column1: 14395`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/cdph/H1N1_swine_flu/FluUpdate_Week1_20100115 (2).pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`   Chicago Department of Public Health   City of Chicago  Richard M. Daley
column2: Mayor   What is the risk?             January 15
column3: 2010   Chicago Department of Public Health  Bechara Choucair
column7: the risk of pandemic influenza A (H1N1) influenza infection in Chicago continues to be  low. The numbers of severe influenza infections
column9: and positive influenza tests have all de- creased.  Due to the possibility of a recurrence of heightened activity in the coming months
column10: all Chicagoans aged  six months and older are encouraged to protect themselves from infection by getting vaccinated with the pandemic  influenza vaccine. Chicagoans should ask their healthcare provider or pharmacist about vaccine availability.  For  those without a healthcare provider or whose healthcare providers do not have the pandemic vaccine
column11: a schedule of  City of Chicago pandemic vaccine clinics1 is available on the City website and by calling 311.   Figure 1. Reported number of hospitalizations associated with  confirmed or presumptive pandemic influenza A (H1N1)
column15: 2010    Figure 2. Percent of patient visits to enrolled doctor’s offices  attributed to influenza-like illness
column18: for current  season (2009-10) and previous two seasons
column19: October-May     Are severe cases of influenza occurring?       Three confirmed or presumptive pandemic   influenza A (H1N1)-associated hospitalizations in  Chicago residents have been reported for surveil- lance week 1 (January 3 –  9
column20: 2010). This is a 98%  decrease from the highest reported weekly count of  the fall
column22: and represents  the ninth consecutive week that a decline has been  noted (figure 1).          How much influenza-like illness is occurring?       With 14 Chicago hospitals reporting
column23: 5.0% of       emergency department visits were due to influenza- like illness (i.e. fever of 100°F or greater
column24: with  cough or sore throat).  This represents the lowest  activity level reported since early October and a  41% decrease from the previous surveillance  week.  Among five outpatient clinics reporting for  the week of January 3 –  9
column26: 3.2% of doctor’s  office visits were due to influenza-like illness.   This level of activity is similar to levels seen dur- ing the same surveillance week during previous  influenza seasons (figure 2).       Which influenza strains are circulating?   For the week of January 3 –  9
column29: all 9 influenza A-positive  specimens for which subtyping was performed  were reported as confirmed or presumptive pan- demic influenza A (H1N1); one influenza B strain  was also reported.          Where can I get more information?                                                                                                                   The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s  FluView2 report provides national updates and trends related to the intensity of influenza activity across the United  States
column30: as well as detailed information on antiviral resistance
column32: and other topics. Updates specific  to Illinois3 and Suburban Cook County4 are also available online.       1http://egov.cityofchicago.org/webportal/COCWebPortal/COC_EDITORIAL/JanuaryScheduleH1N1_enlgish.pdf;   2http://www.cdc.gov/flu/weekly/; 3 http://www.idph.state.il.us/flu/fluupdate08-09.htm; 4 http://www.cookcountypublichealth.org/flu_current_situation

column1: 25151`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/ethics/general/memos/HOLIDAYREMINDER-2017.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`THE ANNUAL HOLIDAY GIFT REMINDER: 2017 VERSION   FROM THE BOARD OF ETHICS          It’s  already  time  for  the  Board’s  annual  grumpy- Scrooge holiday reminder.      As  we  all  know  by  now
column4: subject  to  rules  and  restrictions on what gifts we can receive
column5: whether  during the end-of-year holidays or any other time.        This  brief  guide  explains  the  rules.    Please  follow  them.    Violations  of  these  rules  could  lead  to  employment sanctions
column8: and public shaming.  No gift is worth that.    Remember also to check your own department’s or office’s gift rules
column9: as they may be stricter than  those in the City’s Ethics Ordinance. Ask your departmental ethics officer about that.        THE GIFT RULES:     ○ You can’t solicit or accept any cash or gift card in any amount
column10: unless it falls into one of the limited  exceptions listed below.  ○ You can’t solicit or accept any single non-cash
column13: worth  more  than  $50  from  a  single  source  in  a  calendar  year
column14: unless  it  falls  into  one  of  the  limited  exceptions below.  ○ You can’t accept any anonymous gift
column15: unless it falls into one of the limited exceptions below.  ○ You can’t solicit or accept  anything based on an understanding that your City decisions
column16: actions or  judgments will be affected by it—no exceptions.  ○  You  can’t  accept  a  complimentary  invitation  for  a  vendor’s  holiday  party  unless  you  and  your  department head believe that your attendance is related to your City responsibilities
column17: and you report  it to the Board of Ethics within 10 days. You can
column19: pay your own way.  We recommend that  you do. You are not prohibited from socializing with vendors or others!  ○  These  rules  also  apply  to  gifts  offered  to  or  accepted  by  your  spouse  or  domestic  partner
column20: and  immediate family members living in the same residence as you.     THE LIMITED EXCEPTIONS:   You may solicit or accept:    ● Gifts from your relatives
column22: in any amount;  ● Gifts from a personal friend
column23: unless you have reason to believe that your friend offered you the  gifts because of your City position (we advise that “business friends” are not personal friends – a  personal friend is someone you know independently of your City position);    ● Anything for which you pay fair market value;  ● Anything offered to members of the public on the same terms
column24: like sales promotions or discount  tickets;  ● Gifts you accept on the City's behalf
column25: as long as they’re reported to the Board and City Comptroller  (but  they  must  be  useable  for  City  business  purposes  or  displayed  or  put  out  for  the  public’s  enjoyment – candy or Poinsettias qualify); and  ●  Gifts  offered  to  you  because  of  your  outside
column28: or  community  activity.   GIFTS FROM OTHER CITY PERSONNEL
column29: OFFICE PARTIES     ► City employees may give any gift to co-worker(s) at their level or at a lower pay rate.  ► However
column30: they may not give their official superior(s) any holiday gift other than a non-cash item  or gift card worth $10 or less (even if their superior makes less money).  ► City employees may not solicit co-workers for a gift to any official superior.  ►  Gifts for  “white  elephant
column32: ” or  grab-bag  parties  must  be worth  $10  or  less
column33: and  cannot be cash in any amount.  ► No official superior may ever coerce his or her subordinates into giving or contributing to a gift.  ► For in-office holiday parties
column34: employees may contribute any amount toward food or drinks to be  shared in the office among co-workers.    “Official superior” means any other City employee(s)
column36: whose  official responsibilities include directing or evaluating your performance—and the Mayor himself.    NOTE: You won’t violate the law if you promptly take reasonable action to return a prohibited gift or  transfer any tangible or perishable gift to a tax-exempt charity.    The Board of Ethics will help you figure out whether a gift or specific party plan is acceptable. Please  call us in advance for confidential advice or guidance.  There’s no such thing as a silly question.    Remember: Before accepting any gift
column37: always consider not only whether the law allows you to keep  it
column38: but  whether  your  acceptance  may  create  the  perception  that  your  independent  judgment  or  integrity could be compromised. When in doubt

column1: 20067`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2016construction/oct_2016/20161003_Cermak_CentralPark_24w.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`                    RE:   Water Main Replacement Project #1601025    October 3
column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s Building a New Chicago infrastructure investment  program
column5: I would like to provide you with information about an  upcoming water main construction project in your neighborhood.    By mid October 2016
column6: Department of Water Management (DWM) Benchmark Construction  Company crews will begin the work to install 3
column7: 425 feet of new 8-inch water main in W. Cermak  Road
column8: from S. Millard Avenue to S. Drake Avenue and S. Central Park Avenue
column9: from W. Cermak Road  to W. 26th Street. The old water main dates back to 1890
column10: and needs to be replaced.    If you would like to receive regular email updates about the progress of the project
column11: please go to  BuildingANewChicago.org to register for the WaterALERT program.  Simply enter your name
column12: email address and the project identification number at the top of this letter.   By signing up for the WaterALERT emails
column13: you will be notified as the project enters each new  construction phase – from our mobilization of equipment onto the site
column14: to the installation of new  pipes
column15: to the final restoration of the street.   When we are working in the street
column16: we may close or limit it to traffic for safety reasons
column17: but you will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column18: a travel lane will be left  open for local traffic only.    We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am-4pm).   Parking outside of those hours will be allowed
column19: but cars will need to be moved by the start of the  next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking space as possible.   We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do everything  possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column20: and conducting ourselves as  good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.    Should you have any questions or concerns
column21: you can either ask the construction foreman during the  project
column22: or call any of the following numbers:    •  24-Hour City Service and Information Line:  311  •  24th Ward Office:773-533-2400  •  DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635        Genwmnot03032016          Flushing after Your Service Line has been Connected to the New Water Main    When we switch over the services from the old main to the new water main
column23: we will interrupt water  service.  We give you 24-hour notice when this is to happen.  However
column24: in the event of an emergency  shutdown during construction
column25: we may not be able to give you prior warning.   Now that your old water main has been replaced and your water service has been connected to the  new water main
column26: it is important to flush your plumbing of any sediment
column28: including  any lead to maintain water quality.     Sediment
column30: including any lead may collect in the aerator screen located at the tip of  your faucets.  These screens should be removed prior to flushing.  (1) Please find the closest available tap (an outside  hose spigot
column31: laundry sink faucet or bathtub) to where  the water comes into the home that is not used for  drinking water. Fully open the cold water tap and let  the water run for at least 5 minutes.  Next flush any  other cold water faucets on that floor for at least 5  minutes.   (2)Move to the next highest floor and repeat.  (3) Move to additional floors in sequence and flush          any taps or faucets for at least 5 minutes.      If you have any questions or concerns about your water quality
column32: or if you would like your water  tested
column33: please call us at 311.  For additional advice and information visit  http://www.epa.gov/il/advice-chicago-residents-about-lead-drinking-water.   Routine Flushing  If your water line has been idle or stagnant for more than 6-hours
column34: it is advised that you flush for at  least 5 minutes to maintain water quality.  This may include flushing the toilet
column35: taking a shower and  doing laundry.     MeterSave  Lastly
column36: if you don’t already have one
column37: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter in your  home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free program
column38: go to  www.metersave.org.   Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important infrastructure  improvement project.   Sincerely
